newsitem.title: USA: FOCUS - Gasoline demand seen growing, but slowly.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - Gasoline demand seen growing, but slowly.

text.p: Very high "implied demand" for gasoline overstates real underlying demand and prices are expected to remain fairly tame, even with rising seasonal demand and near record-low inventories, analysts said.

Earlier this week, the American Petroleum Institute showed continued high "implied demand" for gasoline (the sum of stocks drawdown, imports and output) and the Department of Energy also reported a sharp decline in gasoline stocks.
Gasoline futures began a small rally after Wednesday's DOE report which has taken them up about 5.5 percent, to stand at around 63 cents a gallon Friday afternoon.

However, the DOE, which has a much more comprehensive survey of demand, has been running contrary to API "implied demand", showing anemic demand through to the first week in May - about 1.1 percent higher year-on-year.

"We will probably see tight short-term supplies," said Dave Costello, analyst with the Department of Energy's Energy Information Administration (EIA). "But it would take a much greater demand growth rate this summer than we thought to cause problems," he added.

According to figures released by the American Petroleum Institute, implied demand totaled 8.76 million barrels per day last week -- much higher than levels usually seen during the peak demand summer months.

However, the DOE demand four-week average for "gasoline supply" - basically, from the refinery sector to the distribution level - at 7.963 million bpd, up about 90,000 bpd, or 1.1 percent, from the same period last year.
"On a week-to-week basis, the data is a little tricky to use," said Kevin Lindemer of Cambridge Energy Research Associates. "Demand is growing. It's slow growth, but it's there," he added.

Gasoline stocks fell to a meager 193.6 million barrels in the latest reporting week, down 2.4 million barrels from a week ago and about 9.4 million barrels below last year's mark, according to the EIA.
That drop came despite the U.S. refinery output of 7.69 million barrels a day (bpd) and imports averaging 544,000 bpd over the past four weeks.
"We are not assuming stocks will get back to what people call 'normal levels'... It would take some pretty high refinery runs and imports to make that happen," Costello said.
Costello said the DOE forecast for U.S. gasoline demand in the second and third quarter is between 8.1 and 8.2 million barrels a day, an increase of about 1.9 percent from 1996 levels.
To meet expected demand, the U.S. will need to produce about 7.75 to 7.8 million bpd of gasoline, an increase of about 100,000 bpd from year-ago levels, coupled with imports of about 300,000 bpd.
Other factors outside of the immediate supply-demand fundamentals should keep a lid on prices, analysts said.

"Crude oil stocks are pretty high," at around 15 million barrels above last year's levels, said Paulo Nery, senior consultant with Pace Consultants Inc in Houston. "That's why people are not concerned with gasoline stocks."
In addition, traders said U.S. refineries could easily boost their gasoline output if needed, just as the low heating oil inventory level before winter 1996 was met by record production.
"We've seen capacity a lot higher than it is now," said Gerald Samuels, managing director of Arb Oil.
